sentence: Wikipedia editors have a clear preference for adding new sources (Figure 1), which is expected because “recentism” is an established phenomenon on Wikipedia, wherein coverage of recent events is disproportionately greater, and the Wikipedia community itself considers it a factor to be accounted for [18].
In the first two histograms in Figure 2, the blue line that represents the number of references for articles of higher importance is above the green line.

Open in a new tab
Histograms of the number of citations between the two quality groups.If the articles of lower importance were prone to quick referencing by editors with COI, the green histograms in Figure 2 would be much flatter, especially in the new articles (after 2012).
First, we plotted histograms for both importance groups in three time periods (2012 and later, 2007 and later, 2000 and later; Figure 3).
Independent of the time perspective and without focusing on just the important articles, the distributions were similar between both importance groups (Figure 4).
For easier comparison, we overlaid the estimated distributions in Figure 4.

Open in a new tab
Estimated distributions of the number of days between publication and citation on Wikipedia.Figure 4.

Open in a new tab
Comparison of the estimated distributions of the two quality groups.We thereafter analyzed the change in time between publication and citation on Wikipedia over time and the difference between the two importance groups (Figure 5).
The change in the number of citations over time is clearly visible for PNAS (Figure 6).

Each graph includes the name of the journal, the year the journal was founded, and the type of journal access at the top.To better understand the process of dissemination in Wikipedia, we calculated the time from publication to citation for individual journals (Figure 6).
Using ranking instead of the absolute number of citations smoothens out the spikes and influx of citations that followed the creation of Wikipedia (Figure 7).

Wikipedia editors have a clear preference for adding new sources (Figure 1), which is expected because “recentism” is an established phenomenon on Wikipedia, wherein coverage of recent events is disproportionately greater, and the Wikipedia community itself considers it a factor to be accounted for [18].
In the first two histograms in Figure 2, the blue line that represents the number of references for articles of higher importance is above the green line.

Wikipedia editors have a clear preference for adding new sources (Figure 1), which is expected because “recentism” is an established phenomenon on Wikipedia, wherein coverage of recent events is disproportionately greater, and the Wikipedia community itself considers it a factor to be accounted for [18].
In the first two histograms in Figure 2, the blue line that represents the number of references for articles of higher importance is above the green line.
If the articles of lower importance were prone to quick referencing by editors with COI, the green histograms in Figure 2 would be much flatter, especially in the new articles (after 2012).
First, we plotted histograms for both importance groups in three time periods (2012 and later, 2007 and later, 2000 and later; Figure 3).
Independent of the time perspective and without focusing on just the important articles, the distributions were similar between both importance groups (Figure 4).
For easier comparison, we overlaid the estimated distributions in Figure 4.
We thereafter analyzed the change in time between publication and citation on Wikipedia over time and the difference between the two importance groups (Figure 5).
The change in the number of citations over time is clearly visible for PNAS (Figure 6).
To better understand the process of dissemination in Wikipedia, we calculated the time from publication to citation for individual journals (Figure 6).
Using ranking instead of the absolute number of citations smoothens out the spikes and influx of citations that followed the creation of Wikipedia (Figure 7).
